stem: For a minor thermal burn, initial first aid usually involves:

choices.text: Applying grease to seal the skin
Cooling the area with cool running water and seeking care if needed
Popping blisters to relieve pressure
Applying strong solvent

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cooling the area with cool running water and seeking care if needed
Cool the burn with water; avoid ointments/grease initially.

stem: Which oxygen range is considered acceptable for entry into a confined space?

choices.text: 16–18% oxygen
Above 24% oxygen
Any level if wearing a respirator

rationales.CHOICE-2: Atmospheres between ~19.5% and 23.5% oxygen are considered acceptable for entry.

stem: In storage areas, oxygen cylinders should be:

choices.text: Stored together with fuel gas cylinders
Separated from fuel gases by distance or a barrier
Coated with grease to prevent rust
Laid down to save space

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separated from fuel gases by distance or a barrier
Separate oxygen from fuel gases to reduce fire/explosion risk.

stem: When transporting gas cylinders within the shop, you should:

choices.text: Roll them on the bottom rim
Carry them horizontally with two people
Use a proper cylinder cart with cap installed
Drag them by the valve cap

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use a proper cylinder cart with cap installed
Use cylinder carts and keep protective caps on during transport.

stem: Which statement about fire extinguishers is correct?

choices.text: Use water on energized electrical fires
Select an extinguisher rated for the fire class (e.g., ABC for many shop fires)
CO₂ extinguishers are for wood only
Any extinguisher works the same

rationales.CHOICE-2: Select an extinguisher rated for the fire class (e.g., ABC for many shop fires)
Use extinguishers suitable for the fire class; do not use water on energized circuits.

stem: How long should a fire watch typically remain after hot work ends?

choices.text: Not required if the area looks clean
At least 60 minutes
Only while cutting/welding is in progress
At least 30 minutes
Only while cutting is in progress
A fire extinguisher replaces the fire watch

rationales.CHOICE-2: At least 60 minutes
A post‑work fire watch of ~30 minutes is common practice to catch smoldering ignition.

stem: Before hot work near flammable liquids, you should:

choices.text: Ignore containers if closed
Remove or shield them and test the atmosphere if required
Stack them behind a screen
Move closer to finish faster

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove or shield them and test the atmosphere if required
Remove/cover combustibles and verify atmosphere per permit controls.

stem: What device helps prevent flame traveling back into oxy‑fuel hoses?

choices.text: A flowmeter
A check valve or flashback arrestor
A pressure gauge
A hose reel

rationales.CHOICE-2: A check valve or flashback arrestor
Check valves/flashback arrestors reduce flashback risk.

stem: Which clothing is most appropriate for welding?

choices.text: Synthetic athletic wear
Flame‑resistant cotton or leather
Shorts and sandals
Loose acrylic sweater

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flame‑resistant cotton or leather
FR cotton or leather resists ignition and melting.

stem: Before welding, gloves should be:

choices.text: Oily to repel water
Dry and free of holes or tears
Cut‑off fingers for dexterity
Sprayed with solvent

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dry and free of holes or tears
Dry, intact gloves protect from heat and electrical hazards.

stem: What eye and face protection is appropriate for grinding?

choices.text: Safety glasses only
Face shield only
Safety glasses and a face shield together
No eye protection for quick touch‑ups

rationales.CHOICE-3: Safety glasses and a face shield together
Use both safety glasses and a face shield to protect against high‑energy debris.

stem: When noise levels are high during grinding/gouging, workers should:
When noise levels are high during grinding and gouging, workers should:

choices.text: Ignore it for short tasks
Use hearing protection
Wear sunglasses
Use sunglasses
Turn up the radio

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use hearing protection
Hearing protection reduces risk of noise‑induced hearing loss.

stem: After cutting/welding, a good practice for newly heated parts is to:

choices.text: Leave them unmarked
Mark or tag them as 'HOT' and control the area
Cool them with oil
Place them in walkways

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mark or tag them as 'HOT' and control the area
Marking hot parts helps prevent contact burns to others.

stem: When welding outside a designated welding area, a common requirement is to obtain:

choices.text: An equipment calibration sheet
A hot work permit
A shipping manifest
A purchase order

rationales.CHOICE-2: A hot work permit
A hot work permit controls ignition sources and verifies precautions.

stem: How can trip hazards from leads and hoses be reduced?

choices.text: Run them across walkways
Lift them overhead or cover/cross at protected points
Hide them under loose cardboard
Ignore if only a few people pass

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lift them overhead or cover/cross at protected points
Route overhead or cover crossings to reduce tripping.

stem: What is an effective method to control welding fume at the source?

choices.text: Rely on general building ventilation only
Use local exhaust/hoods positioned near the arc
Turn off the extractor to reduce noise
Use a desk fan to blow fumes away

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use local exhaust/hoods positioned near the arc
Capture at the source with local exhaust is most effective.

stem: After isolating and locking equipment, what should be done before starting work?

choices.text: Remove the locks briefly to test
Attempt a start to verify zero energy
Trust only indicator lights
Ask a coworker to avoid touching controls

rationales.CHOICE-2: Attempt a start to verify zero energy
Verification by attempting a start confirms all energy sources are neutralized.

stem: Which statement about welding fumes is correct?

choices.text: They are harmless at normal levels
They can contain manganese and other metal oxides that require control
Only TIG produces fumes
Fumes are eliminated by higher amperage

rationales.CHOICE-2: They can contain manganese and other metal oxides that require control
Many processes produce metal oxide fumes; control exposure with ventilation and PPE.

stem: In case of an emergency evacuation, workers should:

choices.text: Run in different directions
Go to the designated muster/assembly point
Return to collect personal items
Call friends first

rationales.CHOICE-2: Go to the designated muster/assembly point
Assemble at the designated muster point for a headcount.

stem: How should an oxygen cylinder valve be opened for use?

choices.text: Crack it slightly and leave it
Open it fully back‑seated per manufacturer guidance
Open it halfway only
Leave it closed and adjust pressure on the regulator

rationales.CHOICE-2: Open it fully back‑seated per manufacturer guidance
Oxygen valves are designed to be fully opened to seat the packing.

stem: For bench grinding operations, appropriate eye/face protection is:

choices.text: No eye protection for quick jobs
Safety glasses only
Safety glasses plus a face shield
Sunglasses

rationales.CHOICE-3: Use both safety glasses and a face shield for grinding tasks.

stem: Oxy‑fuel/welding hoses should be kept:

choices.text: On sharp edges and hot surfaces
Away from hot/walking areas and protected from damage
choices.stem: Oxy‑fuel and welding hoses should be kept:

choices.text: Across sharp edges and hot surfaces
Away from hot/walking surfaces and protected from damage
Tied in knots for storage
Painted to improve wear resistance
Painted to prevent wear

rationales.CHOICE-2: Away from hot/walking areas and protected from damage
Protect hoses from cuts, heat, and traffic.

choices.stem: Before moving a cylinder to another location, you should:

choices.text: Leave the regulator on for faster setup
Remove the regulator and install the valve cap
Open the valve fully for transport
Lay the cylinder horizontally

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove the regulator and install the valve cap
Remove regulators and install caps before transport.

choices.stem: For tight‑fitting respirators to work properly, the user should:

choices.text: Have facial hair where the seal sits
Have facial hair under the seal
Skip fit testing
Be clean‑shaven where the seal contacts the face
Wear the respirator loosely for comfort

rationales.CHOICE-3: Be clean‑shaven where the seal contacts the face
Facial hair interferes with the seal; fit testing and clean‑shaven seals are required.

choices.stem: For eye protection during arc welding, a safe practice is to choose a filter shade:

choices.text: Based on sunglasses tint
According to amperage and process tables
Always the darkest available
No filter needed for short arcs

rationales.CHOICE-2: According to amperage and process tables
Select shade per tables/guidance for the process and current.

choices.stem: Welding on stainless steel can generate which specific hazard?

choices.text: Helium gas exposure
Hexavalent chromium in fumes
Lead paint overspray only
Ozone‑free air

rationales.CHOICE-2: Hexavalent chromium in fumes
Stainless welding can produce Cr(VI); use controls and PPE per requirements.

choices.stem: Where should SMAW electrode stubs be placed?

choices.text: On the floor near the welder
In a designated stub bucket or container
In the scrap bin with sharp edges exposed
Left in pockets

rationales.CHOICE-2: In a designated stub bucket or container
Use a stub bucket to control sharp waste and keep floors clear.

choices.stem: What helps protect bystanders from arc flash in open areas?

choices.text: Remove PPE
Use welding curtains/screens and post warning signs
Point the arc toward coworkers
Point arc toward coworkers
Turn off ventilation

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use welding curtains/screens and post warning signs
Screens and signage warn and shield others from arc flash.

choices.stem: Why are welding screens used around a work area?

choices.text: Only to improve the welder’s visibility
To protect others from arc flash and flying sparks
To reduce fumes below limits by themselves
To replace personal protective equipment
They only improve the welder’s visibility
They protect others from arc flash and flying sparks
They reduce fumes below limits by themselves
They replace personal protective equipment

rationales.CHOICE-2: To protect others from arc flash and flying sparks
Screens help shield bystanders from UV radiation and ejected particles.

choices.stem: If welding must be performed in damp conditions, you should:

choices.text: Stand in water for stability
Use GFCI protection, dry platforms, and extra insulation
Remove gloves to feel the heat better
Remove gloves to feel the heat
Ignore site rules for speed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use GFCI protection, dry platforms, and extra insulation

choices.stem: Before lighting an oxy‑fuel torch, your first actions should be:

choices.text: Open both torch valves and light with a lighter
Back out regulator screws, slowly and fully open the oxygen cylinder valve, then set pressures and purge lines individually
Fully open the acetylene cylinder valve immediately
Grease threads/fittings for better sealing

rationales.CHOICE-2: Back out regulator screws, slowly and fully open the oxygen cylinder valve, then set pressures and purge lines individually

choices.stem: When working with acetylene cylinders, the cylinder valve is typically opened:

choices.text: Fully to the stop
About 1/2–1 1/2 turns so it can be closed quickly (per manufacturer guidance)
To any random position—it doesn’t matter
Only when moving the cylinder

rationales.CHOICE-2: About 1/2–1 1/2 turns so it can be closed quickly (per manufacturer guidance)

choices.stem: Gas testing in a confined space shows O₂ = 19.2% and 10% LEL. Your decision:

choices.text: Enter; values are close enough to normal
Do not enter; ventilate, eliminate vapor sources, and retest until O₂ ≥ 19.5% and LEL is below the threshold
Enter with a filtering respirator
Have a coworker stand by with an extinguisher

rationales.CHOICE-2: Do not enter; ventilate, eliminate vapor sources, and retest until O₂ ≥ 19.5% and LEL is below the threshold

choices.stem: During welding in the shop, the extraction hood/arm should be positioned:

choices.text: Well away from the arc so it doesn’t block view
As close as possible to the fume source without placing yourself between the arc and the intake
Above the welder’s head so hot air rises into it
Anywhere—general ventilation is enough

rationales.CHOICE-2: As close as possible to the fume source without placing yourself between the arc and the intake

choices.stem: You are welding stainless steel (GMAW) indoors. The most appropriate primary controls are:

choices.text: Open the doors and rely on a draft
Use local exhaust at the arc; add a suitable respirator if the risk assessment requires it
Increase amperage to reduce fume
Use only short tacks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use local exhaust at the arc; add a suitable respirator if the risk assessment requires it

choices.stem: You are laying out a cylinder storage area. A correct solution for O₂ and fuel gases is to:

choices.text: Store them together for convenience
Separate by at least 6.1 m (20 ft) or by a 1.5 m (5 ft) barrier with ~30‑min fire rating
Lay cylinders horizontally and roll them to a wall
Oil the threads for better sealing

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separate by at least 6.1 m (20 ft) or by a 1.5 m (5 ft) barrier with ~30‑min fire rating

choices.stem: You need to dress a part quickly on a bench grinder in a damp area. The safe choice is:

choices.text: No protection—it’s just a minute
Safety glasses + face shield; power through GFCI; dry the work area
Safety glasses only and no extraction
Sunglasses and fingerless gloves

rationales.CHOICE-2: Safety glasses + face shield; power through GFCI; dry the work area

choices.stem: For tight‑fitting respirators used while welding stainless, practical must‑haves are:

choices.text: Stubble under the mask is fine if straps are tight
Be clean‑shaven where the mask seals and complete fit testing per the program
A general room fan is enough
Tighten straps hard over a beard

rationales.CHOICE-2: Be clean‑shaven where the mask seals and complete fit testing per the program
Use dry platforms, GFCI, and insulation to reduce shock risk.
